Dictionary Class

　The Dictionary class is a class for handling dictionary arrays.

　Dictionary arrays are also called associative arrays; they are objects that hold multiple pairs of names and their associated values.
　Like arrays, they are accessed using the [ ] (indirect reference) operator, but strings are used instead of indices, and these strings serve as names. If the name is a valid identifier, the . (direct reference) operator can also be used.
　Additionally, referencing a non-existent name results in void.
　To delete an element, use the delete operator.

Example:
    var d=new Dictionary();
    d["sat"] = 1; // same as d.sat = 1
    d["sun"] = 2; // same as d.sun = 2
    d["mon"] = 3; // same as d.mon = 3
    d["name"] ="value!"; // same as d.name = "value!"
    d["continue"] = 4; // continue is not an identifier, but OK
    d.continue = 4; // continue is not an identifier, so this is an error

    var sat = d["sat"]; // 1 is assigned
    var none = d["none"]; // void is assigned

    delete d.sat; // delete sat
    delete d["continue"]; // delete continue

Dictionary Arrays in Expressions

　Using %[ ], you can describe a Dictionary class object in-place within an expression. List the expressions for the initial elements, separating the element name => element value with commas. For example, if you write:
    var dic = %["a" => 1, "b" => 2, "c" => 3];
　a reference to a Dictionary class object with element name and value pairs "a":1, "b":2, and "c":3 will be assigned to dic.
　Internally, => is exactly the same as a comma, but => can be used for readability (similar to Perl).

Accessing Dictionary Class Methods

　A Dictionary class object has no members when it is first created.
　For example, even if you write dict.assign(src) to use the assign method on a Dictionary class object dict, an error will occur because dict does not have a method named assign.
　Therefore, use the incontextof operator to execute a method belonging directly to the Dictionary class, using the target Dictionary class object as the context.

Example:
    var a = %[];
    var b = %[];
    (Dictionary.assign incontextof a)(b); // copy b to a
    (Dictionary.clear incontextof b)(); // clear the contents of b

saveStruct

　saveStruct outputs structured data to a file.
　Please refer to the same method in the Array Class.

assign

　The assign method copies a dictionary array.

Syntax : assign(<source dictionary array>, <whether to clear contents=true>)
　Copies the contents of another dictionary array specified in the argument exactly.
　If "whether to clear contents" is false, the contents of the copy destination (the object executing the method) are not cleared, and the contents of the source dictionary array are overwritten. If a member with the same name as in the source dictionary array exists in the destination dictionary array, the destination will be overwritten with the source's content.

　If an array (Array class object) is specified as the source, it assumes that the array contains elements that should become members of this dictionary array in the order of name and value, and copies the contents of that array into this dictionary array.

assignStruct

　The assignStruct method copies a dictionary array.

Syntax : assignStruct(<source dictionary array>)
　Copies the contents of another dictionary array specified in the argument exactly.
　Unlike the assign method, if there are arrays or dictionary arrays among the members, their contents are also copied recursively (in the case of the assign method, only the references are copied).

clear

　The clear method clears all contents of the dictionary array.
